quotes.topic_title: Communication and Duolingo’s unique brand voice
quotes.text: And communication isn't about being able to convey a message, it's about being able to convey a message in a way that the listener receives it, and understands it, and remembers it. And that's really hard to do.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: Reframes communication as measured by audience reception and retention, not sender clarity—useful for designing messaging that actually sticks.

quotes.topic_title: Communication and Duolingo’s unique brand voice
quotes.text: One of the things I've helped employ at Duolingo that I think is still there today, it's definitely not just me, it was an amazing team, is a unique voice.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: Highlights “unique voice” as a deliberate, team-driven strategy practitioners can build to differentiate product communication.

quotes.topic_title: Communication and Duolingo’s unique brand voice
quotes.text: There is always a quirk, like it's unexpected.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: Points to “unexpectedness” as a repeatable tactic to increase attention and memorability in user-facing messaging.

quotes.topic_title: Communication and Duolingo’s unique brand voice
quotes.text: Again, it's about how you make people feel.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: Emphasizes emotion as the core metric for effective communication, guiding practitioners to optimize for feeling, not just information transfer.

quotes.topic_title: Communication and Duolingo’s unique brand voice
quotes.text: And you feel like either you giggle, or you're like, wait what? They just did what? And using that to your benefit.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: Gives a concrete model for engineering reactions (humor/surprise) to drive engagement and recall.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Gina is most known for leading growth and marketing at Duolingo, helping take them from 3 million to over 200 million users, primarily through organic and non-paid growth channels, which we explore in depth.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete growth outcome plus the counter-to-default emphasis on organic/non-paid channels as the primary driver.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our wide-ranging conversation, Gina shares a ton of new insights and tactics on how Duolingo grew early on, how they grow today, and most interestingly, what they did to become one of the very rare successful consumer subscription businesses.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical focus on tactics across stages, with a specific emphasis on cracking consumer subscriptions (notoriously difficult).

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We also talk about how every life and career has an A-side and A B-side.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for interpreting careers beyond the highlight reel, useful for decision-making and resilience.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Also, why PR and brand are way underappreciated by most startups.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A contrarian prompt that challenges the common startup bias toward purely performance/paid growth and product-led tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You fell in love with building products for a reason, but sometimes the day-to-Day reality is a little different than you imagined. Instead of dreaming up big ideas, talking to customers and crafting a strategy, you're drowning in spreadsheets and roadmap updates, and you're spending your days basically putting out fires.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor
quotes.context: Captures a common product-management failure mode (reactive busywork) that teams can use as a diagnostic for changing their operating system.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Jira product Discovery, you can gather all your product ideas and insights in one place, and prioritize confidently, finally replacing those endless spreadsheets.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to centralize inputs and replace spreadsheet-driven prioritization with a single source of truth.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Great products are built by great teams, not just engineers.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor
quotes.context: A memorable reminder that product quality is cross-functional, reinforcing broader participation beyond engineering.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And now Hex's AI tools can generate queries and code, create visualizations, and even kickstart a whole analysis for you, all from natural language prompts.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor
quotes.context: A concrete workflow shift: using natural-language prompts to accelerate analysis end-to-end (queries → visuals → initial exploration).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's like having an analytics copilot built right into where you're already doing your work.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor
quotes.context: A sticky mental model (“analytics copilot”) for embedding AI assistance directly in existing analytics workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Latitude conference and Latin America opportunity
quotes.text: There's actually 660 million people living across Latin America, and it's an economy of $6 trillion.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A concrete scale data point that reframes Latin America as a massive market opportunity.

quotes.topic_title: Latitude conference and Latin America opportunity
quotes.text: And helping people get the opportunities that I've had, in terms of access to information and resources that could help them build scalable, very successful startups, can really change the economy across the board.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: Highlights a practical lever for ecosystem-building: improving access to information and resources for founders.

quotes.topic_title: Latitude conference and Latin America opportunity
quotes.text: I believe in that much more than I believe in government, and whether we're going to vote this guy or that guy next.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A contrarian stance that prioritizes entrepreneurship and resource access over political change as the driver of economic outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Latitude conference and Latin America opportunity
quotes.text: And the idea was to share learnings along the way, successes and failures, so that people can skip by not making the same mistakes as others.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: Actionable community design principle: systematically share failures to help others avoid repeating them.

quotes.topic_title: Latitude conference and Latin America opportunity
quotes.text: the first day, the opening talk that I ended up giving was this concept that I really like, which is the A-side and the B-side of a story.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable framework for discussing the polished narrative versus the messy reality behind outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: A-side vs B-side stories framework
quotes.text: We are very encouraged in our lives, especially professionally, to talk about our A-sides all the time.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: Introduces the core A-side/B-side framework and why public narratives skew toward highlight reels.

quotes.topic_title: A-side vs B-side stories framework
quotes.text: It means that a lot of what you hear in podcasts and on stage ends up being the Instagramable version of someone, or a company, or a country's trajectory. It's just the highlights.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A memorable critique of how professional storytelling filters out the messy reality, distorting learning.

quotes.topic_title: A-side vs B-side stories framework
quotes.text: But between all of those highlights, there were so many B-moments that get shoved under the rug because it's just easier for me and it's more impressive for others.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: Explains the incentive structure that hides failures, making it harder for others to calibrate expectations.

quotes.topic_title: A-side vs B-side stories framework
quotes.text: And it's easy to think that things aren't just not going to work out for us because we're in one of those B-moments, if we don't recognize them as moments.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: Actionable reframing: treat setbacks as temporary “B-moments” rather than permanent signals of failure.

quotes.topic_title: A-side vs B-side stories framework
quotes.text: We're at one third of India, one 10th of China, one 30th of the United States.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: Concrete comparative data point supporting the upside case for tech growth in Latin America.

quotes.topic_title: Gina’s B-side setbacks and resilience
quotes.text: My one learning there that has stuck with me, and I think can work for other people too, is that it's not just about doing things that actually matter, and learning. It's about being able to tell the story, and it's about understanding what other people perceive as valuable.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A practical career-growth framework: impact alone isn’t enough—you must communicate it in terms others value.

quotes.topic_title: Gina’s B-side setbacks and resilience
quotes.text: I'm not talking about net value. But I'm talking about, if you want to grow in the world, it's understanding that psychology of how humans react to what you're showing them.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A mental model for influence and advancement: optimize for human perception and reactions, not just objective merit.

quotes.topic_title: Gina’s B-side setbacks and resilience
quotes.text: So there was just a lot of rockiness in my start that I don't think you would imagine when you see someone up on stage leading a conference for 5,000 people. That, I think, is important.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A reframing of “success” that helps practitioners normalize early instability and keep taking shots despite setbacks.

quotes.topic_title: Gina’s B-side setbacks and resilience
quotes.text: So for example, they couldn't figure out how to wire money to Brazil. So I was not paid for six months.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A concrete operational failure example that highlights real-world startup fragility and the need for contingency planning.

quotes.topic_title: Gina’s B-side setbacks and resilience
quotes.text: Did I know anything about these places, Lenny? Did I know people there? No, but you can figure it out.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: Actionable bias-to-action advice: say yes to expansion opportunities and learn fast rather than waiting for perfect readiness.

quotes.topic_title: Careers are long and can pivot
quotes.text: people kind of underestimate how long their career is. There's just so much time to do stuff, and for things to start to work.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Reframes career planning around a longer time horizon, reducing panic and encouraging persistence.

quotes.topic_title: Careers are long and can pivot
quotes.text: as a 26-year-old, I definitely thought my career was over. I was like, I blew it. And looking back, it's funny.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A concrete example that early-career setbacks often feel permanent but are usually temporary in hindsight.

quotes.topic_title: Careers are long and can pivot
quotes.text: I spent nine years at my first job, at a random company in San Diego in a startup. And I was like, what am I doing here so long? And it turned out that was really useful for the thing I did next.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Shows how seemingly slow or “stuck” periods can compound into valuable experience for the next role.

quotes.topic_title: Careers are long and can pivot
quotes.text: This is my fourth career. I've switched careers many times. I was an engineer, then I was a founder, then I was a product manager. And now I'm whatever this is, whatever you call this thing.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Normalizes multiple career reinventions as a viable path rather than a sign of inconsistency.

quotes.topic_title: Careers are long and can pivot
quotes.text: Just, there's a lot of time to do stuff. And don't stress if things aren't moving as fast as you want.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable advice to reduce anxiety and stay focused on long-term progress over short-term speed.

quotes.topic_title: Bloomberg campaign: optimizing post-click conversion
quotes.text: And after maybe a few days there, I realized that my best bet in terms of actually adding value was not to be another cook in the kitchen trying to figure that out, but to move into the next step of the journey, which nobody was paying attention to.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A practical prioritization framework: when acquisition is crowded, create leverage by optimizing the neglected post-click funnel.

quotes.topic_title: Bloomberg campaign: optimizing post-click conversion
quotes.text: Which is, once you click on an ad, you land somewhere. And then whatever happens there is super important. Because if people then take the action you want them to take on that landing page, or don't, is definitive.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: Re-centers growth work on post-click conversion as the decisive step, not the ad itself.

quotes.topic_title: Bloomberg campaign: optimizing post-click conversion
quotes.text: And even just the second or third screen in an experience are as, if not more, important than the first one. Because that's where your "leaky buckets" can happen.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A memorable mental model (“leaky buckets”) for why downstream funnel steps often matter more than top-of-funnel polish.

quotes.topic_title: Bloomberg campaign: optimizing post-click conversion
quotes.text: So if you're able to 2X the effectiveness of a landing page, you are able to actually, in a compounded way, increase the effectiveness of that first ad.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: Highlights the compounding ROI of conversion-rate improvements versus only scaling ad spend.

quotes.topic_title: Bloomberg campaign: optimizing post-click conversion
quotes.text: There was one day where I brought one page from three to 12% conversion rate with statistical significance.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A concrete data point showing how rapid iteration at high spend can produce outsized conversion gains quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Landing page tactics: mobile, skimmable, emotional
quotes.text: The first one is making it mobile-optimized.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: She highlights mobile-first optimization as the highest-leverage, often-overlooked landing page conversion improvement.

quotes.topic_title: Landing page tactics: mobile, skimmable, emotional
quotes.text: First, the core copy, the message and button need to be above the fold. Or, if you're not going to keep the button above the fold, which I still recommend, but if you're not going to do that for whatever reason, then you need to have a very clear indicator that there's something to scroll towards on your page.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A concrete mobile landing-page rule: ensure immediate clarity and a visible CTA (or an explicit cue to scroll).

quotes.topic_title: Landing page tactics: mobile, skimmable, emotional
quotes.text: The second thing, applies to both desktop and mobile, is people skim.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A behavioral reality that drives copy and layout choices: design for skimmers, not readers.

quotes.topic_title: Landing page tactics: mobile, skimmable, emotional
quotes.text: Having the title and the button speak to each other is really cool. Because if people only read the title and the button, they got it.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A simple messaging alignment heuristic: the headline and CTA should fully communicate the offer even if nothing else is read.

quotes.topic_title: Landing page tactics: mobile, skimmable, emotional
quotes.text: But fear really inspires people, and that's just a truth about human psychology.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: She emphasizes using emotion intentionally (e.g., fear) as a lever to drive action when appropriate to the context.

quotes.topic_title: Why Duolingo succeeded as consumer subscription
quotes.text: More specifically, you can double or triple your income potential by learning English in a developing market like Latin America.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A concrete, outcome-based articulation of the mission that can anchor positioning, prioritization, and messaging.

quotes.topic_title: Why Duolingo succeeded as consumer subscription
quotes.text: It helped us hire the best people even if we were based in Pittsburgh and couldn't necessarily pay the Google dollars.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: Shows how mission clarity can function as a recruiting lever when you can’t compete on compensation or location.

quotes.topic_title: Why Duolingo succeeded as consumer subscription
quotes.text: When I was hired by Duolingo as a consultant and as an employee, my mandate was make Duolingo grow. Here is no budget. I had no budget.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A vivid example of forcing-function constraints that push teams toward organic growth and retention-first thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Why Duolingo succeeded as consumer subscription
quotes.text: So we didn't have an LTV, which meant that having a CAC made no sense.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A crisp unit-economics mental model for why paid acquisition can be premature before monetization is proven.

quotes.topic_title: Why Duolingo succeeded as consumer subscription
quotes.text: Then you become completely dependent, and it's really hard to turn it off. So it's almost like an addiction, that as much as you're able to limit in the beginning, the better.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that paid growth can create lock-in and fragility even when early CAC looks great.

quotes.topic_title: Product rigor: data-driven iteration over copying
quotes.text: And unless you're able to own that data and understand what it can tell you, you're never going to win.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: Emphasizes that durable product advantage comes from owning and learning from your data, not just shipping features.

quotes.topic_title: Product rigor: data-driven iteration over copying
quotes.text: But then as I started talking to them, I understand they don't have the engineers and PMs there looking at Mixpanel or whatever it is that they're using every day, understanding how every single change is leading to other changes that enables them to ask the questions and come up with the hypotheses that allow them to get to the next step.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A concrete methodology: daily instrumentation review + causal thinking + hypothesis-driven iteration as the real engine behind “Duolingo-like” outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Product rigor: data-driven iteration over copying
quotes.text: You know how I think of that? It's like those students who are able to copy the best student's answer on the math test, and then they get frustrated that they didn't get an A because the work wasn't there, but they copied the answer.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: Memorable mental model for why copying UI/outputs fails without the underlying problem-solving process.

quotes.topic_title: Product rigor: data-driven iteration over copying
quotes.text: It's certainly the case in Latin America, where people think they can outsource the code or outsource the growth, and they're not just looking like hawks at the quality of the data and statistical significance and running hypotheses and questioning them.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: Counterpoint to “outsource execution” thinking: rigorous measurement and experimentation can’t be delegated if you want compounding product learning.

quotes.topic_title: Duolingo failures: badges, social duels, launches
quotes.text: More than 50% of our AB tests didn't work out.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark that normalizes failure rates in experimentation and sets expectations for teams running lots of A/B tests.

quotes.topic_title: Duolingo failures: badges, social duels, launches
quotes.text: And we ran this very simple experiment that was like, "You sign up and then you get a badge."
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: An example of an overly-lean MVP that strips away the core value of a feature, leading to misleading test results.

quotes.topic_title: Duolingo failures: badges, social duels, launches
quotes.text: Looking back, we hadn't been dogfooding in the growth team.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A practical process lesson: using your own product would have caught obvious issues before running experiments.

quotes.topic_title: Duolingo failures: badges, social duels, launches
quotes.text: Because once you have badges and people want them, you can now ask people to do anything like go find friends, go buy things, whatever it is.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A reusable growth mechanism: create a valued reward currency, then attach desired behaviors to it across the product.

quotes.topic_title: Duolingo failures: badges, social duels, launches
quotes.text: We launched Duolingo in India and didn't realize because we couldn't have unless we went there, which we finally did, that most people set their phone UI in India to English, because typing in Hindi is hard, and of course there's a lot of languages throughout India.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A localization cautionary tale showing why on-the-ground discovery can reveal critical user behavior that analytics assumptions miss.

quotes.topic_title: Dogfooding and trusting instincts in product work
quotes.text: Versus just use the thing, see what feels wrong and keeps you from being excited and really trust that.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical dogfooding heuristic: your own friction and lack of excitement can be a strong signal for what to fix without over-researching.

quotes.topic_title: Dogfooding and trusting instincts in product work
quotes.text: Just don't underestimate the power of you just using it and relying on instincts and feelings you have when you're trying to use it.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Encourages practitioners to treat first-person product usage as valid input for prioritization and iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Dogfooding and trusting instincts in product work
quotes.text: But you have to, and I think that forcing yourself to pretend that you know answers and just finding out what this pretend person who would know all the answers would think is really helpful because it helps you develop your point of view, your voice, and to trust yourself, even when you're working on something that you don't fully understand.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for building conviction: role-play the “confident expert” to develop your own product judgment over time.

quotes.topic_title: Dogfooding and trusting instincts in product work
quotes.text: When you're able to understand that when you don't get something, probably other people don't get it too at scale.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A counterintuitive scaling insight: your personal confusion can be a leading indicator of widespread UX failure.
